commit_message:
improve support matrix notes

This cleans up the support matrix by:

 - Making format, phrasing, and terminology more consistent
 - Correcting errors, e.g. a reference to nova-network where neutron
   also applies
 - Moving driver-specific comments from the general notes to
   driver-notes-<driver>
 - Adding more information, e.g. maintenance mode deprecation
 - Removing redundant statements, e.g. saying something is optional
   when that is already indicated by the status field
 - Removing notes that do not help driver developers or end users,
   e.g. commentary on "a cloud model".
 - Removing sections that are not needed, e.g. operation.firewall
   had nothing to distinguish it from operation.securitygroups

During the process of checking some of these notes for accuracy, it
was discovered that one of the source files where multiattach is
implemented has a significant error in the comment about qemu and
libvirt version requirements. That is fixed here as well rather than
split a comment correction into its own commit.

Change-Id: Ibba91bcd67c167ed16461e70c49e9dd0da97e8a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/34/540534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # - partial - implemented, but with caveats about when it will work, # e.g. some configurations or hardware or guest operating systems # may not support ittitle=Attach volume to instancenotes=Attaches additional block storage to an existing server instance. The attach may be executed while the instance is running, allowing expansion of storage capabilities without interruption of service.title=Attach tagged volume to instancenotes=Attaches a block device with a tag to an existing server instance. See "Attach volume to instance" and "Device tags" for more information.title=Detach volume from instancenotes=Detaches a block storage device from an existing server instance. The detach may be executed while the instance is running, allowing storage removal without interruption of service.notes=Extends the size of an attached volume. The extension may be executed while the instance is running, allowing volume expansion without interruption of service.notes=Attaches an additional network interface to an existing server instance. The attach may be executed while the instance is running, allowing expansion of interface capabilities without interruption of service. Hotplug support varies between guest operating systems and some guests require a reboot for new interfaces to be detected.driver-notes-hyperv=Works without issue if instance is off. When hotplugging, only works if using Windows/Hyper-V Server 2016 and the instance is a Generation 2 VM.notes=Attaches a virtual network interface with a tag to an existing server instance. See "Attach virtual network interface to instance" and "Device tags" for more information.notes=Detaches a virtual network interface from an existing server instance. The detach may be executed while the instance is running, allowing interface removal without interruption of service.driver-notes-hyperv=Works without issue if instance is off. When hotplugging, only works if using Windows/Hyper-V Server 2016 and the instance is a Generation 2 VM.title=Set host maintenance modenotes=Places a host into maintenance mode, automatically triggering migration of any running instances to an alternative host and preventing new instances from being launched. This is a system-level operation which should be outside of the control of the compute service and is therefore deprecated.title=Evacuate instance from a hostnotes=Evacuates a server instance from a host that is down to another host. Volumes get re-attached but the locally stored data is dropped, similar to a rebuild.notes=Recreates a server instance with specified information such as 'metadata' and 'personalities. Volumes get re-attached but the locally stored data is dropped. A possible use case is that additional attributes need to be set on the instance.notes=Provides realtime information about the power state of the guest instance. This operation is considered mandatory because the power state is used by the compute manager for tracking changes in guests.notes=Provides host uptime since power on as a component of hypervisor status.notes=Provides the ip of the host. This is important for resize and migration.notes=Moves a running server instance from one host to another host. Administrators may use this to remove instances from a host that needs to undergo maintenance, to move an instance to a host with more capacity prior to a resize, or any number of other reasons. This operation is optional because it is technically challenging for some hypervisors to provide support for live migration, particularly those built on container based virtualization.notes=Forces the in-progress live migration of a given server instance to complete. Live migration may sometimes fail to complete if an instance has a high rate of memory or disk page access, in which case forcing the completion may become necessary. The mechanism used to complete the live migration depends on the underlying virtualization subsystem's capabilities. E.g. if libvirt/qemu is used and the post-copy feature is available and enabled then the force complete operation will cause a switch to post-copy mode. Otherwise the instance will be suspended until the migration is completed or aborted.notes=Creates a new virtual machine instance. This is manadatory since importing pre-existing virtual machines is not supported.notes=Stops a server instance's CPUs. This can be thought of as roughly equivalent to suspend-to-RAM. The instance is still present in memory, but execution has stopped. The problem, however, is that without a mechanism to inform the guest operating system that this has taken place, its clocks will no longer report the correct time upon unpausing. For this reason hypervisor vendors generally discourage use of this feature and some do not even implement it.notes=Reboots a server instance. Both soft (graceful) and hard reboots may be requested. A host-initiated graceful reboot will require guest co-operation.notes=Starts a server instance in a special configuration whereby it is booted from a special root disk image, allowing an administrator to recover a broken virtual machine.notes=Resizes a server instance to match a different flavor. The resize may be executed while the instance is running. It is technically challenging for hypervisors to support the alteration of all relevant config settings for a running instance. See driver notes for specific limitations.driver-notes-vz-vm=Resizing Virtuozzo instances implies guest filesystem resizedriver-notes-vz-ct=Resizing Virtuozzo instances implies guest filesystem resizenotes=Resumes a server instance that was previously suspended. See "Suspend instance" for more information.notes=Provides a mechanism to (re)set the password of the operating system's administrator account for a running server instance. This requires that the hypervisor has a way to communicate with the running guest operating system. Given the wide range of operating systems in existence it is unreasonable to expect this to be practical in the general case.notes=Saves and uploads the current state of a server instance's root disk to the glance image repository. New instances can subsequently be launched from this saved image.notes=Suspends a server instance. This can be thought of as roughly equivalent to suspend-to-disk. The instance no longer consumes any RAM or CPU, while its live running state is preserved in a file on disk. It can later be restored, at which point it should continue execution where it left off. As with stopping instance CPUs, it suffers from the fact that the guest operating system will typically be left with a clock that no longer reports the correct time. For container based virtualization solutions, this operation is particularly technically challenging to implement and is an area of active research.notes=Swaps out a volume attached to a server instance for a different volume. This overwrites all data on the new volume with data from the old volume.notes=Shuts down a running server instance. This operation is required to avoid indefinite resource usage and billing.driver-notes-libvirt-lxc=Fails in latest Ubuntu Trusty kernel from security repository (3.13.0-76-generic), but works in upstream 3.13.x kernels as well as default Ubuntu Trusty latest kernel (3.13.0-58-generic).notes=Triggers a dump of server instance memory to a file. This is typically implemented by injecting a non-maskable interrupt (NMI) into the instance.notes=Resumes a server instance's CPUs. See "Stop instance CPUs (pause)" for more information.notes=Resizes and partitions the server instance's root disk to match the size specified by flavors.root_gb during a resize operation.notes=Limits disk I/O. The ability to set rate limits on virtual disks allows for greater performance isolation between instances using the same storage.notes=Provides a special configuration drive attached to a server instance at boot time as an information channel for guest operating system setup. This enables configuration of the administrator password, registration of SSH keys, file injection, etc. Since cloud images frequently have all login methods locked, drivers must support at least one of the guest setup mechanisms.notes=Injects user-provided files into the root filesystem before a server instance is booted. This requires that the compute node understand the format of the filesystem and any partitioning scheme it might use on the block device, which is a non-trivial problem considering the vast number of filesystems in existence. The problem of injecting files into a guest operating system is better solved by obtaining those files via the metadata service or config drive.notes=Injects static network configuration (IP address, netmask, gateway, and routes) into the root filesystem before a server instance is booted. This requires that the compute node understand how networking is configured in the guest operating system, which is a non-trivial problem considering the vast number of operating system types. The problem of configuring networking is better solved by DHCP or by obtaining static configuration via config drive.notes=Provides interactive access to a server instance's graphical console using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). If the guest operating system supports RDP, this may serve as a way to access the system when network-based access is not an option.notes=Provides read-only access to a server instance's serial console. This may be useful for diagnosing problems when an instance fails to boot successfully.notes=Provides interactive access to a server instance's serial console. This may serve as a way to access the system when network-based access is not an option.notes=Provides interactive access to a server instance's graphical console using the Simple Protocol for Independent Computing Environments (SPICE). If the hypervisor supports SPICE, this may serve as a way to access the system when network-based access is not an option.notes=Provides interactive access to the graphical console of a server instance using Virtual Network Computing (VNC). If the hypervisor or guest operating system supports VNC, this may serve as a way to access the system when network-based access is not an option.notes= Block storage provides instances with direct attachednotes=Provides the ability to attach volumes from a Fibre Channel storage provider.status=optional notes=Provides the ability to attach volumes from an iSCSI storage provider.notes=Provides the ability to use the Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) when attaching iSCSI volumes. Requiring authentication is an important security measure for traffic on untrusted networks.notes=Provides the ability to boot an instance from an image stored in the glance image repository. Without this feature it would not be possible to bootstrap from a clean environment, since there would be no way to get block volumes populated and reliance on external PXE servers is out of scope.[networking.securitygroups] title=Network security groupsnotes=Provides a way to define rules that isolate the network traffic of different instances running on a compute host. This feature is deprecated in favor of support in the network service.driver-impl-powervm=missingnotes=Provides network connectivity to guests using a flat topology across all compute nodes.notes=Provides network connectivity to guests using a VLAN topology.title=UEFI bootnotes=This allows users to boot a guest with UEFI firmware.notes=Sets tags on virtual devices when creating a server instance. Device tags are used to identify virtual device metadata, as exposed via the metadata API or on the config drive. For example, the order of multiple networks in a server instance launch request will not necessarily be reflected in the order of those networks as they appear in the guest operating system, so device tags should be used rather than device order to deduce information about the attached network devices. See "Attach tagged virtual network interface to instance" and "Attach tagged volume to instance" for more information.notes=Freezes the file systems of a running server instance during a snapshot to make the snapshot consistent. Must subsequently unfreeze the file systems once the snapshot is complete.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-x86=QEMU Guest Agent must be enabled.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=QEMU Guest Agent must be enabled.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-s390x=QEMU Guest Agent must be enabled.driver-notes-libvirt-qemu-x86=QEMU Guest Agent must be enabled.notes=Attaches an already-attached volume to another server instance. This is an extension of the attach volume operation, which would otherwise only allow attachment when the volume is not already attached.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-x86=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-s390x=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.driver-notes-libvirt-qemu-x86=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.driver-notes-libvirt-xen=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.driver-notes-libvirt-vz-vm=Only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.
deleted_lines: # - partial - implemented, but with caveats about when it will work # eg some configurations or hardware or guest OS may not # support ittitle=Attach block volume to instancenotes=The attach volume operation provides a means to hotplug additional block storage to a running instance. This allows storage capabilities to be expanded without interruption of service. In a cloud model it would be more typical to just spin up a new instance with large storage, so the ability to hotplug extra storage is for those cases where the instance is considered to be more of a pet than cattle. Therefore this operation is not considered to be mandatory to support.title=Attach tagged block device to instancenotes=Attach a block device with a tag to an existing server instance. See "Device tags" for more information.title=Detach block volume from instancenotes=See notes for attach volume operation.notes=The extend volume operation provides a means to extend the size of an attached volume. This allows volume size to be expanded without interruption of service. In a cloud model it would be more typical to just spin up a new instance with large storage, so the ability to extend the size of an attached volume is for those cases where the instance is considered to be more of a pet than cattle. Therefore this operation is not considered to be mandatory to support.notes=The attach interface operation provides a means to hotplug additional interfaces to a running instance. Hotplug support varies between guest OSes and some guests require a reboot for new interfaces to be detected. This operation allows interface capabilities to be expanded without interruption of service. In a cloud model it would be more typical to just spin up a new instance with more interfaces.driver-notes-hyperv=Works without issue if instance is off. When hotplugging, only works if using Windows/Hyper-V Server 2016 and the instance is a Generation 2 VM.notes=Attach a virtual network interface with a tag to an existing server instance. See "Device tags" for more information.notes=See notes for attach-interface operation.driver-notes-hyperv=Works without issue if instance is off. When hotplugging, only works if using Windows/Hyper-V Server 2016 and the instance is a Generation 2 VM.title=Set the host in a maintenance modenotes=This operation allows a host to be placed into maintenance mode, automatically triggering migration of any running instances to an alternative host and preventing new instances from being launched. This is not considered to be a mandatory operation to support. The driver methods to implement are "host_maintenance_mode" and "set_host_enabled".title=Evacuate instances from a hostnotes=A possible failure scenario in a cloud environment is the outage of one of the compute nodes. In such a case the instances of the down host can be evacuated to another host. It is assumed that the old host is unlikely ever to be powered back on, otherwise the evacuation attempt will be rejected. When the instances get moved to the new host, their volumes get re-attached and the locally stored data is dropped. That happens in the same way as a rebuild. This is not considered to be a mandatory operation to support.notes=A possible use case is additional attributes need to be set to the instance, nova will purge all existing data from the system and remakes the VM with given information such as 'metadata' and 'personalities'. Though this is not considered to be a mandatory operation to support.notes=Provides realtime information about the power state of the guest instance. Since the power state is used by the compute manager for tracking changes in guests, this operation is considered mandatory to support.notes=Returns the result of host uptime since power on, it's used to report hypervisor status.notes=Returns the ip of this host, it's used when doing resize and migration.notes=Live migration provides a way to move an instance off one compute host, to another compute host. Administrators may use this to evacuate instances from a host that needs to undergo maintenance tasks, though of course this may not help if the host is already suffering a failure. In general instances are considered cattle rather than pets, so it is expected that an instance is liable to be killed if host maintenance is required. It is technically challenging for some hypervisors to provide support for the live migration operation, particularly those built on the container based virtualization. Therefore this operation is not considered mandatory to support.notes=Live migration provides a way to move a running instance to another compute host. But it can sometimes fail to complete if an instance has a high rate of memory or disk page access. This operation provides the user with an option to assist the progress of the live migration. The mechanism used to complete the live migration depends on the underlying virtualization subsystem capabilities. If libvirt/qemu is used and the post-copy feature is available and enabled then the force complete operation will cause a switch to post-copy mode. Otherwise the instance will be suspended until the migration is completed or aborted.notes=Importing pre-existing running virtual machines on a host is considered out of scope of the cloud paradigm. Therefore this operation is mandatory to support in drivers.notes=Stopping an instances CPUs can be thought of as roughly equivalent to suspend-to-RAM. The instance is still present in memory, but execution has stopped. The problem, however, is that there is no mechanism to inform the guest OS that this takes place, so upon unpausing, its clocks will no longer report correct time. For this reason hypervisor vendors generally discourage use of this feature and some do not even implement it. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support in drivers.notes=It is reasonable for a guest OS administrator to trigger a graceful reboot from inside the instance. A host initiated graceful reboot requires guest co-operation and a non-graceful reboot can be achieved by a combination of stop+start. Therefore this operation is considered optional.notes=The rescue operation starts an instance in a special configuration whereby it is booted from an special root disk image. The goal is to allow an administrator to recover the state of a broken virtual machine. In general the cloud model considers instances to be cattle, so if an instance breaks the general expectation is that it be thrown away and a new instance created. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support in drivers.notes=The resize operation allows the user to change a running instance to match the size of a different flavor from the one it was initially launched with. There are many different flavor attributes that potentially need to be updated. In general it is technically challenging for a hypervisor to support the alteration of all relevant config settings for a running instance. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support in drivers.driver-notes-vz-vm=Resizing Virtuozzo instances implies guest filesystem resize alsodriver-notes-vz-ct=Resizing Virtuozzo instances implies guest filesystem resize alsonotes=See notes for the suspend operationnotes=Provides a mechanism to (re)set the password of the administrator account inside the instance operating system. This requires that the hypervisor has a way to communicate with the running guest operating system. Given the wide range of operating systems in existence it is unreasonable to expect this to be practical in the general case. The configdrive and metadata service both provide a mechanism for setting the administrator password at initial boot time. In the case where this operation were not available, the administrator would simply have to login to the guest and change the password in the normal manner, so this is just a convenient optimization. Therefore this operation is not considered mandatory for drivers to support.notes=The snapshot operation allows the current state of the instance root disk to be saved and uploaded back into the glance image repository. The instance can later be booted again using this saved image. This is in effect making the ephemeral instance root disk into a semi-persistent storage, in so much as it is preserved even though the guest is no longer running. In general though, the expectation is that the root disks are ephemeral so the ability to take a snapshot cannot be assumed. Therefore this operation is not considered mandatory to support.notes=Suspending an instance can be thought of as roughly equivalent to suspend-to-disk. The instance no longer consumes any RAM or CPUs, with its live running state having been preserved in a file on disk. It can later be restored, at which point it should continue execution where it left off. As with stopping instance CPUs, it suffers from the fact that the guest OS will typically be left with a clock that is no longer telling correct time. For container based virtualization solutions, this operation is particularly technically challenging to implement and is an area of active research. This operation tends to make more sense when thinking of instances as pets, rather than cattle, since with cattle it would be simpler to just terminate the instance instead of suspending. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support.notes=The swap volume operation is a mechanism for changing a running instance so that its attached volume(s) are backed by different storage in the host. An alternative to this would be to simply terminate the existing instance and spawn a new instance with the new storage. In other words this operation is primarily targeted towards the pet use case rather than cattle, however, it is required for volume migration to work in the volume service. This is considered optional to support.notes=The ability to terminate a virtual machine is required in order for a cloud user to stop utilizing resources and thus avoid indefinitely ongoing billing. Therefore this operation is mandatory to support in drivers.driver-notes-libvirt-lxc=Fails in latest Ubuntu Trusty kernel from security repository (3.13.0-76-generic), but works in upstream 3.13.x kernels as well as default Ubuntu Trusty latest kernel (3.13.0-58-generic).notes=The trigger crash dump operation is a mechanism for triggering a crash dump in an instance. The feature is typically implemented by injecting an NMI (Non-maskable Interrupt) into the instance. It provides a means to dump the production memory image as a dump file which is useful for users. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support.notes=See notes for the "Stop instance CPUs" operationnotes=Partition and resize FS to match the size specified by flavors.root_gb, As this is hypervisor specific feature. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support.notes=The ability to set rate limits on virtual disks allows for greater performance isolation between instances running on the same host storage. It is valid to delegate scheduling of I/O operations to the hypervisor with its default settings, instead of doing fine grained tuning. Therefore this is not considered to be an mandatory configuration to support.notes=The config drive provides an information channel into the guest operating system, to enable configuration of the administrator password, file injection, registration of SSH keys, etc. Since cloud images typically ship with all login methods locked, a mechanism to set the administrator password or keys is required to get login access. Alternatives include the metadata service and disk injection. At least one of the guest setup mechanisms is required to be supported by drivers, in order to enable login access.notes=This allows for the end user to provide data for multiple files to be injected into the root filesystem before an instance is booted. This requires that the compute node understand the format of the filesystem and any partitioning scheme it might use on the block device. This is a non-trivial problem considering the vast number of filesystems in existence. The problem of injecting files to a guest OS is better solved by obtaining via the metadata service or config drive. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support.notes=This allows for static networking configuration (IP address, netmask, gateway and routes) to be injected directly into the root filesystem before an instance is booted. This requires that the compute node understand how networking is configured in the guest OS which is a non-trivial problem considering the vast number of operating system types. The problem of configuring networking is better solved by DHCP or by obtaining static config via config drive. Therefore this operation is considered optional to support.notes=This allows the administrator to interact with the graphical console of the guest OS via RDP. This provides a way to see boot up messages and login to the instance when networking configuration has failed, thus preventing a network based login. Some operating systems may prefer to emit messages via the serial console for easier consumption. Therefore support for this operation is not mandatory, however, a driver is required to support at least one of the listed console access operations.notes=This allows the administrator to query the logs of data emitted by the guest OS on its virtualized serial port. For UNIX guests this typically includes all boot up messages and so is useful for diagnosing problems when an instance fails to successfully boot. Not all guest operating systems will be able to emit boot information on a serial console, others may only support graphical consoles. Therefore support for this operation is not mandatory, however, a driver is required to support at least one of the listed console access operations.notes=This allows the administrator to interact with the serial console of the guest OS. This provides a way to see boot up messages and login to the instance when networking configuration has failed, thus preventing a network based login. Not all guest operating systems will be able to emit boot information on a serial console, others may only support graphical consoles. Therefore support for this operation is not mandatory, however, a driver is required to support at least one of the listed console access operations. This feature was introduced in the Juno release with blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/serial-portsnotes=This allows the administrator to interact with the graphical console of the guest OS via SPICE. This provides a way to see boot up messages and login to the instance when networking configuration has failed, thus preventing a network based login. Some operating systems may prefer to emit messages via the serial console for easier consumption. Therefore support for this operation is not mandatory, however, a driver is required to support at least one of the listed console access operations.notes=This allows the administrator to interact with the graphical console of the guest OS via VNC. This provides a way to see boot up messages and login to the instance when networking configuration has failed, thus preventing a network based login. Some operating systems may prefer to emit messages via the serial console for easier consumption. Therefore support for this operation is not mandatory, however, a driver is required to support at least one of the listed console access operations.notes=Block storage provides instances with direct attachednotes=To maximise performance of the block storage, it may be desirable to directly access fibre channel LUNs from the underlying storage technology on the compute hosts. Since this is just a performance optimization of the I/O path it is not considered mandatory to support.status=condition(storage.block==complete) notes=If the driver wishes to support block storage, it is common to provide an iSCSI based backend to access the storage from cinder. This isolates the compute layer for knowledge of the specific storage technology used by Cinder, albeit at a potential performance cost due to the longer I/O path involved. If the driver chooses to support block storage, then this is considered mandatory to support, otherwise it is considered optional.notes=If accessing the cinder iSCSI service over an untrusted LAN it is desirable to be able to enable authentication for the iSCSI protocol. CHAP is the commonly used authentication protocol for iSCSI. This is not considered mandatory to support. (?)notes=This refers to the ability to boot an instance from an image stored in the glance image repository. Without this feature it would not be possible to bootstrap from a clean environment, since there would be no way to get block volumes populated and reliance on external PXE servers is out of scope. Therefore this is considered a mandatory storage feature to support.[networking.firewallrules] title=Network firewall rulesnotes=Unclear how this is different from security groupsdriver-impl-powervm=complete [networking.routing] title=Network routing status=optional notes=Unclear what this refers to cli= driver-impl-xenserver=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=missing driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-s390x=complete driver-impl-libvirt-qemu-x86=complete driver-impl-libvirt-lxc=complete driver-impl-libvirt-xen=complete driver-impl-vmware=complete driver-impl-hyperv=missing driver-impl-ironic=complete driver-impl-libvirt-vz-vm=complete driver-impl-libvirt-vz-ct=complete driver-impl-powervm=complete [networking.securitygroups] title=Network security groups status=optional notes=The security groups feature provides a way to define rules to isolate the network traffic of different instances running on a compute host. This would prevent actions such as MAC and IP address spoofing, or the ability to setup rogue DHCP servers. In a private cloud environment this may be considered to be a superfluous requirement. Therefore this is considered to be an optional configuration to support. cli= driver-impl-xenserver=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-s390x=complete driver-impl-libvirt-qemu-x86=complete driver-impl-libvirt-lxc=complete driver-impl-libvirt-xen=complete driver-impl-vmware=partial driver-notes-vmware=This is supported by the Neutron NSX plugins driver-impl-hyperv=missing driver-impl-ironic=missing driver-impl-libvirt-vz-vm=complete driver-impl-libvirt-vz-ct=complete driver-impl-powervm=completenotes=Provide network connectivity to guests using a flat topology across all compute nodes. At least one of the networking configurations is mandatory to support in the drivers.notes=Provide network connectivity to guests using VLANs to define the topology when using nova-network. At least one of the networking configurations is mandatory to support in the drivers.title=uefi bootnotes=This allows users to boot a guest with uefi firmware.notes=This allows users to set tags on virtual devices when creating a server instance. Device tags are used to identify virtual device metadata, as exposed in the metadata API and on the config drive. For example, a network interface tagged with "nic1" will appear in the metadata along with its bus (ex: PCI), bus address (ex: 0000:00:02.0), MAC address, and tag (nic1). If multiple networks are defined, the order in which they appear in the guest operating system will not necessarily reflect the order in which they are given in the server boot request. Guests should therefore not depend on device order to deduce any information about their network devices. Instead, device role tags should be used. Device tags can be applied to virtual network interfaces and block devices.notes=Quiesce the specified instance to prepare for snapshots. For libvirt, guest filesystems will be frozen through qemu agent.driver-impl-libvirt-lxc=missing driver-impl-libvirt-xen=missing driver-impl-vmware=missing driver-impl-hyperv=missing driver-impl-ironic=missing driver-impl-libvirt-vz-vm=missing driver-impl-libvirt-vz-ct=missing driver-impl-powervm=missing [operation.unquiesce] title=unquiesce status=optional notes=See notes for the quiesce operation cli= driver-impl-xenserver=missing driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-s390x=complete driver-impl-libvirt-qemu-x86=completenotes=The multiattach volume operation is an extension to the attach volume operation. It allows to attach a single volume to multiple instances. This operation is not considered to be mandatory to support. Note that for the libvirt driver, this is only supported if qemu<2.10 or libvirt>=3.10.

commit_message:
Ironic: Get IP address for volume connector from ports/portgroups

When iSCSI storage network is managed by neutron, an IP address for a
volume connector cannot be registered by an operator in advance. The IP
address of the connector may be required from some cinder backend
drivers. A port representing a NIC or a portgroup representing a pair
of bonded NICs can be registered as a volume connector for an Ironic
node.

This patch gets an IP address for a volume connector from a port
or a portgroup associated with the volume connector by seeing a VIF
attached to the port or the portgroup.

Implements: blueprint ironic-volume-connector-ip
Change-Id: Iea089e2a9232352211268f91dfec6cf79f8bfac0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/22/517322/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: vif_id = (self._get_vif_from_macs(node, values.get('mac', [])) or self._get_vif_from_ports(values.get('port', [])) or self._get_vif_from_portgroups(values.get('portgroup', []))) def _get_vif_port_id(self, p): return (p.internal_info.get('tenant_vif_port_id') or p.extra.get('vif_port_id')) vif_id = self._get_vif_port_id(p) def _get_vif_from_ports(self, port_uuids): for port_uuid in port_uuids: port = self.ironicclient.call('port.get', port_uuid) vif_id = self._get_vif_port_id(port) if vif_id: return vif_id return None def _get_vif_from_portgroups(self, pgroup_uuids): for pgroup_uuid in pgroup_uuids: pgroup = self.ironicclient.call('portgroup.get', pgroup_uuid) vif_id = self._get_vif_port_id(pgroup) if vif_id: return vif_id return None
deleted_lines: vif_id = self._get_vif_from_macs(node, values.get('mac', [])) vif_id = (p.internal_info.get('tenant_vif_port_id') or p.extra.get('vif_port_id'))

commit_message:
Add rabbitmq_erlang_cookie tag for rabbitmq config

The puppet base profile invokes rabbitmq module that sets erlang cookie
via the rabbitmq_erlang_cookie provider, but default puppet tags omit
it. This ends up with hiera setting never applied for non-HA rabbitmq
container configs.

The HA one is not affected as it sets the cookie via explicit file
resource in the rabbitmq_bundle manifest.

Change-Id: I9cd1b773b4d4cc4cb2f4ea46015639770a037495
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/69/714969/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

'}]
commit_message:
Move is_block_device_mapping to new_format_is_volume

driver.block_device.is_block_device_mapping had only 1 caller:
ComputeManager._default_block_device_names(). It was inconsistent with
the other methods called by that function, and additionally its name
did not accurately represent what it did.

This also removes the last caller of is_implemented, so we remove it.

Change-Id: I01be8dc24f806c4575932f0a4bff7f7bff3f077b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/17/511217/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: _IMPLEMENTED_CLASSES = (DriverSwapBlockDevice, DriverEphemeralBlockDevice, DriverVolumeBlockDevice, DriverSnapshotBlockDevice, DriverImageBlockDevice, DriverBlankBlockDevice) def is_implemented(bdm): for cls in _IMPLEMENTED_CLASSES: try: cls(bdm) return True except _NotTransformable: pass return False def is_block_device_mapping(bdm): return (bdm.source_type in ('image', 'volume', 'snapshot', 'blank') and bdm.destination_type == 'volume' and is_implemented(bdm))

commit_message:
Add gateway chassis rebalance script

This patch adds new command:

    networking-ovn-rebalance-gw-chassis

which could be used to rebalance load across configured
gateway chassis [1]. Please be aware that use of it could
lead to temporary N/S traffic flap.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/653718/

Change-Id: I3d0a4d01e33edb68af6dcdaf30926e393a26be9c
Closes-Bug: #1732580
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/46/663046/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2019 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import re import sys from neutron.common import config from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl import idlutils from networking_ovn.ovsdb import impl_idl_ovn LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ChassisRebalancer(object): def __init__(self, nb_idl, sb_idl): self._nb_idl = nb_idl self._sb_idl = sb_idl def get_all_master_ports(self, chassis=None): chassis_gw_ports = {} cr_ports = self._sb_idl.db_find_rows( 'Port_Binding', ('type', '=', 'chassisredirect')).execute(check_error=True) for port in cr_ports: try: chassis_name = port.chassis[0].name except IndexError: # TODO(mjozefcz): Sometimes first call fails on # lazy loading with IndexError('list index out of range',) # Find out how to prevent that. chassis_name = port.chassis[0].name if chassis and not chassis == chassis_name: continue provnet = self.get_provider_net_name(port.logical_port) cr_lrp_data = { 'uuid': port.uuid, 'name': port.logical_port, 'chassis_name': chassis_name, 'provnet': provnet, } # Construct chassis_name -> master bind dict chassis_gw_ports[port.logical_port] = cr_lrp_data return chassis_gw_ports def get_chassis_with_master_ports(self, provnet=None, chassis=None): master_ports = self.get_all_master_ports() found_chassis = {} for port, cl_lrp_data in master_ports.items(): # Filter out unwanted provnets if provnet and provnet not in cl_lrp_data.get('provnet'): continue chassis_name = cl_lrp_data.get('chassis_name') # Filter out unwanted chassis if chassis and chassis != chassis_name: continue try: cr_lrps_count = ( found_chassis.get(chassis_name)['cr_lrps_count'] + 1) except Exception: cr_lrps_count = 1 try: cr_lrps = found_chassis.get(chassis_name)['cr_lrps'] cr_lrps.append(cl_lrp_data) except Exception: cr_lrps = [cl_lrp_data] found_chassis.update({ chassis_name: { 'cr_lrps_count': cr_lrps_count, 'cr_lrps': cr_lrps } }) return found_chassis def get_provider_net_name(self, cr_lrp): # cr-lrp -> lrp -> lp -> datapath_binding -> providernet lp_name = re.sub('cr-lrp-', '', cr_lrp) lp = self._sb_idl.db_find_rows( 'Port_Binding', ('logical_port', '=', lp_name)).execute(check_error=True) datapath = self._sb_idl.db_find_rows( 'Datapath_Binding', ('uuid', '=', lp[0].datapath.uuid)).execute(check_error=True) return datapath[0].external_ids.get('name2') def get_candidates_for_lrp(self, lrp, provnet): # Get candidates with priority lrp = idlutils.row_by_value( self._nb_idl, 'Logical_Router_Port', 'name', lrp) chassis_list = self._nb_idl._get_logical_router_port_gateway_chassis( lrp) gw_with_lrps = self.get_chassis_with_master_ports(provnet=provnet) candidates = [] for candidate in chassis_list: # Construct tuples, easy to sort # chassis_name, prio num_of_hosted_lrps try: cr_lrp_count = gw_with_lrps.get(candidate[0])['cr_lrps_count'] except KeyError: # chassis has no cr_lrp bound cr_lrp_count = 0 candidates.append((candidate[0], candidate[1], cr_lrp_count)) return candidates def get_all_chassis_with_provnet(self, provnet): found_chassis = set() chassis_provnet_mappings = self._sb_idl.get_chassis_and_physnets() for k, v in chassis_provnet_mappings.items(): if provnet in v: found_chassis.add(k) return found_chassis def get_master_ports_with_provnet(self, provnet): gw_ports = self.get_all_master_ports() found = {} for k, v in gw_ports.items(): if v.get('provnet') == provnet: found[k] = v return found def get_avg_per_provnet(self, provnet): chassis_num = len(self.get_all_chassis_with_provnet(provnet)) master_gw_num = len(self.get_master_ports_with_provnet(provnet)) try: return int(round(master_gw_num / chassis_num)) except Exception: return 0 def get_all_provnets(self): chassis_provnet_mappings = self._sb_idl.get_chassis_and_physnets() provnets = set([provnet for provnets in chassis_provnet_mappings.values() for provnet in provnets]) return provnets def rebalance_gw_chassis(self, chassis_to_rebalance, provnet, max_per_chassis): if not chassis_to_rebalance: return for chassis, data in chassis_to_rebalance.items(): for cr_lrp in data.get('cr_lrps'): if cr_lrp.get('provnet') != provnet: # gateway not related to balanced provnet continue # Find out if this chassis is rebalanced yet # or we need some more movements. actual_gateways = self.get_chassis_with_master_ports( provnet=provnet, chassis=chassis) count = actual_gateways.get(chassis)['cr_lrps_count'] if count <= max_per_chassis: LOG.info("Chassis %s has been rebalanced", chassis) break lrp = re.sub('cr-', '', cr_lrp.get('name')) candidates = self.get_candidates_for_lrp(lrp, provnet) if len(candidates) < 2: LOG.warning("Can't rebalance %s due to lack of " "candidates.", lrp) continue # Sort candidates by least-loaded candidates = sorted(candidates, key=lambda x: x[2]) can_names = [can[0] for can in candidates] # Move actual chassis to the end of the list can_names.append(can_names.pop(can_names.index(chassis))) with self._nb_idl.transaction(check_error=True) as txn: txn.add(self._nb_idl.update_lrouter_port( lrp, gateway_chassis=can_names)) LOG.info("Gateway chassis for LRP: %(lrp)s has been modified. " "Actual priority list: %(candidates)s", {'lrp': lrp, 'candidates': can_names}) def start(self): LOG.info("Starting rebalance of gateway chassis") # NOTE(mjozefcz): # chassis_with_the_same_provider_network -> candidates # -> master_chassis # So if we find loaded chassis we should move master to # at least loaded chassis from candidates pool. provnets = self.get_all_provnets() for provnet in provnets: chassis_to_rebalance = {} # It's kind of assumption about AVG, becuase we have # another layer which is candidates. # We 'hope' that OVNGatewayLeastLoadedScheduler # and rescheduler mechanism will properly select # candidates pool to be spread across whole available # chassis with access to needed provider net. avg_per_chassis = self.get_avg_per_provnet(provnet) max_per_chassis = avg_per_chassis + 1 gw_chassis = self.get_chassis_with_master_ports(provnet=provnet) for chassis, data in gw_chassis.items(): if data.get('cr_lrps_count') > max_per_chassis: chassis_to_rebalance.update({ chassis: { 'cr_lrps': data.get('cr_lrps') } }) LOG.info("AVG gateways per chassis in provider network: " "%(provnet)s is %(avg)s. Chassis %(chassis)s " "has %(count)s gateways in this provider " "network and needs to be rebalanced.", {'provnet': provnet, 'avg': avg_per_chassis, 'count': data.get('cr_lrps_count'), 'chassis': chassis}) self.rebalance_gw_chassis( chassis_to_rebalance, provnet, max_per_chassis) LOG.info("End of rebalancer run.") def get_connections(): try: conn = impl_idl_ovn.get_connection(impl_idl_ovn.OvsdbNbOvnIdl) ovn_nb_api = impl_idl_ovn.OvsdbNbOvnIdl(conn) except RuntimeError: LOG.error('Invalid ovn_nb_connection parameter provided.') return try: sb_conn = impl_idl_ovn.get_connection(impl_idl_ovn.OvsdbSbOvnIdl) ovn_sb_api = impl_idl_ovn.OvsdbSbOvnIdl(sb_conn) except RuntimeError: LOG.error('Invalid ovn_sb_connection parameter provided.') return return ovn_nb_api, ovn_sb_api def main(): """Main method used for rebalancing load gateway chassis. This tool spreads router load across gateway chassis. """ config.init(sys.argv[1:]) logging.setup(cfg.CONF, 'networking-ovn') nb_idl, sb_idl = get_connections() rebalancer = ChassisRebalancer(nb_idl, sb_idl) rebalancer.start()

commit_message:
Disable voting for tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode

We need to disable it just for a moment to have [1] merged.
After that we're going to propose RDO patch and then revert
this one.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663046

Change-Id: Ie55161edefbcb96146bcf4ede4db464472c37bf3

commit_message:
[DNM] Add syslog dump and key dump

In case of failed auth dump syslog logs and installed public
keys.

Change-Id: Iccc47d61ccd3ce57cc1cf218217ec7a84fdc8203
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/54/699954/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
def _dump_auth_logs(self, host): # Login to server using password LOG.debug('Dumping additional info for host %s', host) ssh_client = ssh.Client(host, 'cirros', password='cubswin:)') messages = ssh_client.exec_command('cat /var/log/messages') installed_keys = ssh_client.exec_command('cat /home/cirros/.ssh/authorized_keys') LOG.debug('/var/log/messages output for %s
body=
%s', host, messages) LOG.debug('/home/cirros/.ssh/authorized_keys output for %s
body=
%s', host, installed_keys) self._dump_auth_logs(host)

subject: Enable heat tempest plugin for undercloud
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-30 13:54:47.000000000', 'files': ['config/general_config/featureset027.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/11e4f403427cbea5c3e91ea9ff802cdc2f1ff61f', 'message': 'Enable heat tempest plugin for undercloud

Heat is heavily used in tripleo deployment. It is necessary to make
sure heat api works fine.

Enabling heat tempest plugin api tests might help.

Change-Id: Ibbca48f7f04cc46a7878b8c6f68225eabbabc6e7
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Enable heat tempest plugin for undercloud

Heat is heavily used in tripleo deployment. It is necessary to make
sure heat api works fine.

Enabling heat tempest plugin api tests might help.

Change-Id: Ibbca48f7f04cc46a7878b8c6f68225eabbabc6e7
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/13/705013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tempest_service_available_heat: true - 'heat_tempest_plugin.tests.api'

subject: Port several legacy tempest jobs to Zuul v3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-07-21 20:44:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f288b2705f7bb3e083c8c40028657df42de8040d', 'message': 'Port the legacy multibackend jobs to Zuul v3

- cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend is the simple LVM multibackend job
  and replaces legacy-tempest-dsvm-lvm-multibackend. As the legacy name
  is used by other repositories (devstack and tempest), define an alias;
- cinder-tempest-zeromq-multibackend is a de-facto variation of
  cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend (hence the inheritance) and
  replaces legacy-tempest-dsvm-zeromq-multibackend.

commit_message:
Port several legacy tempest jobs to Zuul v3

- cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend is the simple LVM multibackend job
  and replaces legacy-tempest-dsvm-lvm-multibackend.
- remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-zeromq-multibackend, as ZeroMQ
  support was deprecated in Rocky and removed in Stein.
  It could be replaced by inheriting from
  cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend in older branches
  when this patch is backported;
- replace cinder-tempest-dsvm-lvm-lio-barbican with
  cinder-tempest-dsvm-lvm-lio-barbican provided by
  cinder-tempest-plugins;
- replace legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-nfs with
  devstack-plugin-nfs-tempest-full, now provided by
  devstack-plugin-nfs;
- update cinder-plugin-ceph-tempest to also run cinderlib tests
  and make it inherit from devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest-py3.

Change-Id: Icdafaf55494b6dd74ec31c3572d7344fcc028166
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/45/671945/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend: - cinder-tempest-zeromq-multibackend: - job: name: cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend parent: devstack-tempest description: | Cinder tempest job based on LVM and multiple backends, and cinderlib tests. Former names for this job where: * legacy-tempest-dsvm-lvm-multibackend timeout: 10800 run: playbooks/tempest-and-cinderlib-run.yaml required-projects: - opendev.org/openstack/cinderlib - opendev.org/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin vars: tox_envlist: all tempest_test_regex: '(?!.*\[.*\bslow\b.*\])(^tempest\.(api|scenario)|(^cinder_tempest_plugin))' tempest_plugins: - cinder-tempest-plugin devstack_localrc: CINDER_ENABLED_BACKENDS: 'lvm:lvmdriver-1,lvm:lvmdriver-2' irrelevant-files: *gate-irrelevant-files - job: name: legacy-tempest-dsvm-lvm-multibackend parent: cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend description: | Temporary job needed by devstack and tempest - job: name: cinder-tempest-zeromq-multibackend parent: cinder-tempest-lvm-multibackend description: | Cinder tempest job based on LVM, zeroMQ and multiple backends, and cinderlib tests. commit_message:
Use global hosts entries to configure /etc/hosts

Global hosts entry block is evaluated via the HostsEntry stack output.
That one is joined from VipHosts and HostsEntryValue values stored in
Heat, which already take into account the UndercloudHostsEntries,
VipHosts, ExtraHostFileEntries and roles' hosts_entry.

So there is no need to duplicate extra entries via additional
parameters and ansible vars. Just use that HostsEntry as a single
source of truth for ansible role that configures the ultimate /etc/hosts
state.

Related-Bug: #1868588
Change-Id: I09d02a008070e066cf9c2f9b7e93824f43e6d985
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/714409
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/11/714611/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: name: tripleo_hosts_entries # uses global hosts_entry
deleted_lines: UndercloudHostsEntries: default: [] description: > List of undercloud hosts entries to be appended to /etc/hosts. The value is populated with the HEAT_HOSTS entries on the undercloud by tripleoclient when running deploy. type: comma_delimited_list ExtraHostsEntries: default: [] description: List of extra hosts entries to be appended to /etc/hosts type: comma_delimited_list VipHostsEntries: default: [] description: List of VIP (virtual IP) hosts entries to be appended to /etc/hosts type: comma_delimited_list undercloud_hosts_entries: {get_param: UndercloudHostsEntries} extra_hosts_entries: {get_param: ExtraHostsEntries} vip_hosts_entries: {get_param: VipHostsEntries} name: tripleo_hosts_entries vars: tripleo_hosts_entries_undercloud_hosts_entries: "{{ undercloud_hosts_entries }}" tripleo_hosts_entries_extra_hosts_entries: "{{ extra_hosts_entries }}" tripleo_hosts_entries_vip_hosts_entries: "{{ vip_hosts_entries }}"

commit_message:
Configure main registry as trunk.registry.rdoproject.org

Container registry for promotions moved to vexxhost and got
back its hostname: trunk.registry.rdoproject.org
No need to use "vexxhost" specific one.
Change-Id: I75b21dc7ec7a2594e5ffa1a26547b6dc4950bba7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/21/715021/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: docker_registry_host: trunk.registry.rdoproject.org

subject: Do not race when applying puppet/rsync in containers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-25 13:37:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/79c2d0bd7281ee45d4f0a4351b694dd317df79b2', 'message': "Do not race when applying puppet/rsync in containers

When puppet configures related service containers, like ironic
or nova services, there is potential rsync --delete-after race
condition with other rsync or puppet executions in parallel
containers.

Use flock to coordinate those. When a lock cannot be acquired for
either puppet or rsync after a 10 sec timeout, just fail it and allow
for retries to handle it.

In order to discover related config containers, use the common part of
its config volume prefixes. For example, container-puppet-nova_libvirt
and container-puppet-nova_api will have their shared locks stored in
the host's /var/lock/containers/nova/container-puppet dir also
bind-mounted as /var/lock/container-puppet for any of the other
container-puppet-nova_* config containers.

Also, in order to keep the timestamps of the puppet-generated/rsynced
files clean and isolated, release the lock only after all the required
timestamp-sensitive manipulations are done. That also provides better
isolation of configs and fences related services from unnecessary
restarts caused by unrelated config changes. Even if any made it
into config files having the same name, like nova.conf, but in fact
had been targeting different nova services.

Change-Id: I486ebf009cc1fc7d1cf2ce947fdd5c112930d125
Closes-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d38ec4ec26e06086b05b0b6534dc4639e977af44)

commit_message:
Do not race when applying puppet/rsync in containers

When puppet configures related service containers, like ironic
or nova services, there is potential rsync --delete-after race
condition with other rsync or puppet executions in parallel
containers.

Use flock to coordinate those. When a lock cannot be acquired for
either puppet or rsync after a 10 sec timeout, just fail it and allow
for retries to handle it.

In order to discover related config containers, use the common part of
its config volume prefixes. For example, container-puppet-nova_libvirt
and container-puppet-nova_api will have their shared locks stored in
the host's /var/lock/containers/nova/container-puppet dir also
bind-mounted as /var/lock/container-puppet for any of the other
container-puppet-nova_* config containers.

Also, in order to keep the timestamps of the puppet-generated/rsynced
files clean and isolated, release the lock only after all the required
timestamp-sensitive manipulations are done. That also provides better
isolation of configs and fences related services from unnecessary
restarts caused by unrelated config changes. Even if any made it
into config files having the same name, like nova.conf, but in fact
had been targeting different nova services.

Change-Id: I486ebf009cc1fc7d1cf2ce947fdd5c112930d125
Closes-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d38ec4ec26e06086b05b0b6534dc4639e977af44)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/42/714942/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errno echo 'Locking it for puppet' exec {lock_fd}>/var/lock/container-puppet/busy.lock || exit 1 # In case other puppet or rsync already locked it, we just wait for a 10 sec. flock -w 10 "$lock_fd" || exit 1 echo 'Unlocking it after puppet' flock -u "$lock_fd" echo 'Locking it for rsync' exec {lock_fd}>/var/lock/container-puppet/busy.lock || exit 1 # In case other puppet rt rsync already locked it, we just wait for a 10 sec. flock -w 10 "$lock_fd" || exit 1 echo 'Unlocking it after rsync' sync flock -u "$lock_fd" # Locks management (shared via a common config volume prefix) '--volume', '/var/lock/containers/%s:' '/var/lock/container-puppet' % config_volume.split('_')[0]

Change-Id: I486ebf009cc1fc7d1cf2ce947fdd5c112930d125
Closes-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d38ec4ec26e06086b05b0b6534dc4639e977af44)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-03-25 13:38:39.000000000', 'files': ['common/container-puppet.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/bc84f9a62a46ea2713ecf116fad0973489d2009e', 'message': "Do not race when applying puppet/rsync in containers

When puppet configures related service containers, like ironic
or nova services, there is potential rsync --delete-after race
condition with other rsync or puppet executions in parallel
containers.

Use flock to coordinate those. When a lock cannot be acquired for
either puppet or rsync after a 10 sec timeout, just fail it and allow
for retries to handle it.

In order to discover related config containers, use the common part of
its config volume prefixes. For example, container-puppet-nova_libvirt
and container-puppet-nova_api will have their shared locks stored in
the host's /var/lock/containers/nova/container-puppet dir also
bind-mounted as /var/lock/container-puppet for any of the other
container-puppet-nova_* config containers.

Also, in order to keep the timestamps of the puppet-generated/rsynced
files clean and isolated, release the lock only after all the required
timestamp-sensitive manipulations are done. That also provides better
isolation of configs and fences related services from unnecessary
restarts caused by unrelated config changes. Even if any made it
into config files having the same name, like nova.conf, but in fact
had been targeting different nova services.

Change-Id: I486ebf009cc1fc7d1cf2ce947fdd5c112930d125
Closes-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d38ec4ec26e06086b05b0b6534dc4639e977af44)
"}]
commit_message:
Do not race when applying puppet/rsync in containers

When puppet configures related service containers, like ironic
or nova services, there is potential rsync --delete-after race
condition with other rsync or puppet executions in parallel
containers.

Use flock to coordinate those. When a lock cannot be acquired for
either puppet or rsync after a 10 sec timeout, just fail it and allow
for retries to handle it.

In order to discover related config containers, use the common part of
its config volume prefixes. For example, container-puppet-nova_libvirt
and container-puppet-nova_api will have their shared locks stored in
the host's /var/lock/containers/nova/container-puppet dir also
bind-mounted as /var/lock/container-puppet for any of the other
container-puppet-nova_* config containers.

Also, in order to keep the timestamps of the puppet-generated/rsynced
files clean and isolated, release the lock only after all the required
timestamp-sensitive manipulations are done. That also provides better
isolation of configs and fences related services from unnecessary
restarts caused by unrelated config changes. Even if any made it
into config files having the same name, like nova.conf, but in fact
had been targeting different nova services.

Change-Id: I486ebf009cc1fc7d1cf2ce947fdd5c112930d125
Closes-bug: #1868934
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d38ec4ec26e06086b05b0b6534dc4639e977af44)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/40/714940/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errno echo 'Locking it for puppet' exec {lock_fd}>/var/lock/container-puppet/busy.lock || exit 1 # In case other puppet or rsync already locked it, we just wait for a 10 sec. flock -w 10 "$lock_fd" || exit 1 echo 'Unlocking it after puppet' flock -u "$lock_fd" echo 'Locking it for rsync' exec {lock_fd}>/var/lock/container-puppet/busy.lock || exit 1 # In case other puppet rt rsync already locked it, we just wait for a 10 sec. flock -w 10 "$lock_fd" || exit 1 echo 'Unlocking it after rsync' sync flock -u "$lock_fd" # Prepare the path used for shared locks among related containers # as podman needs host paths existing in order to bind-mount it related_prefix = config_volume.split('_')[0] try: os.mkdir('/var/lock/containers/%s' % related_prefix) except OSError as e: if e.errno == errno.EEXIST: pass else: raise e '--volume', '/dev/log:/dev/log:rw'], # Locks management (shared via a common config volume prefix) '--volume', '/var/lock/containers/%s:' '/var/lock/container-puppet:rw' % related_prefix

commit_message:
[tests] Improve devstack/post playbook efficiency

By adjusting the syntax to the newer format, the fetch-subunit
role will be skipped entirely, rather than run with all its
tasks skipped. This gives us results sooner and burns less
electricity, making the world a better place. :)

Change-Id: I6ae5a63051d512eecb2a603af9d74ec139eb0877
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/52/715052/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Move py35 jobs to latest python3

glanceclient-tox-py35-keystone-tips and glanceclient-tox-py35-oslo-tips
jobs run on py35 which should be moved the newer python3 version.

Moving them to py3 env so that they can pickup the available
python version on running node.

Change-Id: I5fadbadf9eee2163ef6d17af2ceb49883151038c

commit_message:
libvirt: Use virDomainBlockCopy to swap volumes when using -blockdev

Previously virDomainBlockRebase [1] was used by swap_volume to switch
between volumes presented to the compute host as block devices or files.

As outlined in the virDomainBlockCopy [2] documentation this command is
actually a superset of virDomainBlockRebase in our case:

> This command is a superset of the older virDomainBlockRebase() when used
> with the VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_REBASE_COPY flag, and offers better control
> over the destination format, the ability to copy to a destination that
> is not a local file, and the possibility of additional tuning
> parameters.

As such we can switch to virDomainBlockCopy and expand support for
swap_volume outside of just host block devices and files.

To allow swap_volume to support RBD volumes we also need the domain to
use the recently introduced -blockdev support within libvirt >= 6.0.0
and QEMU >= 4.2.0. New MIN_LIBVIRT_BLOCKDEV and MIN_QEMU_BLOCKDEV
version constants are introduced and used to determine when to switch to
the virDomainBlockCopy method of moving between volumes.

[1] https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainBlockRebase
[2] https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainBlockCopy

Closes-Bug: #1868996
Change-Id: I8e8035dcf508f5215bba9b7575c5c6abfe41da31

added_lines: def copy(self, dest_xml, shallow=False, reuse_ext=False, transient=False): """Copy the guest-visible contents into a new disk http://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainBlockCopy param: dest_xml: XML describing the destination disk to copy to shallow: Limit copy to top of source backing chain reuse_ext: Reuse existing external file for a copy transient: Don't force usage of recoverable job for the copy operation """ # https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainBlockCopyFlags # noqa flags = shallow and libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_COPY_SHALLOW or 0 flags |= reuse_ext and libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_COPY_REUSE_EXT or 0 flags |= transient and libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_COPY_TRANSIENT_JOB or 0 return self._guest._domain.blockCopy(self._disk, dest_xml, flags=flags)

This reverts commit 4b535151897b353523fd1589468f98fed3357309.

commit_message:
libvirt: Use oslo.utils >= 4.1.0 to fetch format-specific image data

This change is a follow up to I0c3f14100a18107f7e416293f3d4fcc641ce5e55
and removes the direct call to nova.privsep.qemu with one to the images
API that now returns an oslo_utils.imageutils.QemuImgInfo object.
Version 4.1.0 of oslo.utils introducing support for the format-specific
data returned by qemu-img info for LUKSv1 based images.

Change-Id: I573396116e10cf87f80f1ded55f2cd8f498859e4

standalone ironic.

commit_message:
Re-use swift_store_cacert for Keystone session

pass configured cacert for Swift to the keystoneauth's Session
as well so that the swift endpoint can be resolved from the catalog
when a custom CA bundle is used.

Change-Id: I439f6b5af34c685f72c9b4933c7eb0c77cc92e14
Closes-Bug: #1820817

commit_message:
Add VLAN type conntrack direct flow

For vlan type network, we add a segment match flow
to the openflow security group ingress table. Then
the packets will be recorded in conntrack table, and
the reply packets can be processed properly.

Conflicts:
    doc/source/contributor/internals/openvswitch_firewall.rst

Change-Id: Ieded0654d0ad16235ec923b822dcd842bd7735e5
Closes-Bug: #1831534
(cherry picked from commit aa58542e823d23d233524cd5639c7ec4bb757769)

commit_message:
Add 'description' field to the device profile object

Add the DeviceProfile objects version 1.1, and add 'description'
field to the DeviceProfile's fields.
And 'description' also will expose to end users from
the GET/POST response body.

Story: 2007397
Partial-Implements: blueprint add-description-field-to-device-profiles

Change-Id: I15fd9a430d09b20b55375b374fd7fd96542c6358

added_lines: from oslo_utils import versionutils # Version 1.1: Added description field. VERSION = '1.1' # TODO(brinzhang): Convert to uncompatible version 'description':object_fields.StringField(nullable=True), } def obj_make_compatible(self, primitive, target_version): super(DeviceProfile, self).obj_make_compatible( primitive, target_version) target_version = versionutils.convert_version_to_tuple(target_version) if target_version < (1, 1) and 'description' in primitive: del primitive['description']

commit_message:
Add description column to device_profiles db

Add 'description' column to the ``device_profiles`` table,
and changes the ``DeviceProfile`` model.

Partial-Implements: blueprint add-description-field-to-device-profiles

Change-Id: I42ad7ee7dffa7348e80ccdb35a5d19db6d58c637
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cyborg refs/changes/85/703285/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """add_description_field_to_dps Revision ID: 60d8ac91fd20 Revises: 7a4fd0fc3f8c Create Date: 2020-01-19 16:15:04.231512 """ # revision identifiers, used by Alembic. revision = '60d8ac91fd20' down_revision = '7a4fd0fc3f8c' from alembic import op import sqlalchemy as sa def upgrade(): op.add_column('device_profiles', sa.Column('description', sa.Text(), nullable=True))

Optimize the tempest job for zaqar-tempest-plugin

No need to copy the playbooks from zaqar, just use 'parent'.

commit_message:
Improve the accuracy of device profile API responses in docs

Now when we called the device profiles POST/GET API, that will return
response body, but in API docs, the responses body missing "created_at"
and "updated_at" fields, this commits add these missing properties
in device profile API docs.

Another change is that the adjustment responses are worth the correct
order.

Change-Id: I37817da2a8f7ee2aa2f6dd5b7ab2188c2035cefb

commit_message:
Fix es2 issues and add es7 support.

1.When put template, there is no http headers,
so request would be failed.
2.Now, es storage is based on es 2.x,
it is out of date.

Change-Id: I05afcd15650f3f98ed57c6c850984b68faf4ae7a
Signed-off-by: yuanrunsen <yuanrunsen@unitedstack.com>

but a fixed 'mariadb' name.

Change-Id: Ie8efa509953d5efa5c3073c9b550be051a7f4f9b

commit_message:
mariadb container name variable

mariadb container name variable is fixed in some places,
but in the defaults directory, mariadb container_name variable
is variable. If the mariadb container_name variable is changed
during deployment, it will not be assigned to container_name,
but a fixed 'mariadb' name.

Change-Id: Ie8efa509953d5efa5c3073c9b550be051a7f4f9b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/24/714824/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: command: "docker exec mariadb mysql -h {{ database_address }} -P {{ database_port }} -u haproxy -e 'show databases;'"

commit_message:
Add realtime support to drive conversion

This patch updates change_physical_disk_state() so that it returns the
actual results of drive conversion on each controller.  This allows the
caller to use the returned information for realtime drive conversion.

This patch also deprecates returning the is_reboot_required and
commit_required_ids keys in the dictionary.

Change-Id: I10f4a44660e70f0cd8efd0ca9e8e96cb46751a61
(cherry picked from commit ff312640d8af2b2b18ab08bf725a4ee8f2e99bcf)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-dracclient refs/changes/31/715031/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy :param controllers_to_physical_disk_ids: Dictionary of controllers and corresponding disk ids to convert to the requested mode. :returns: a dictionary mapping controller FQDDs to the list of physical disks that need to be converted for that controller. controllers_to_physical_disk_ids = copy.deepcopy( controllers_to_physical_disk_ids) return controllers_to_physical_disk_ids """Convert disks RAID status This method intelligently converts the requested physical disks from RAID to JBOD or vice versa. It does this by only converting the disks that are not already in the correct state. :param mode: constants.RaidStatus enumeration that indicates the mode to change the disks to. corresponding disk ids to convert to the requested mode. :returns: a dictionary containing: - conversion_results, a dictionary that maps controller ids to the conversion results for that controller. The conversion results are a dict that contains: - The is_commit_required key with the value always set to True indicating that a config job must be created to complete disk conversion. - The is_reboot_required key with a RebootRequired enumerated value indicating whether the server must be rebooted to complete disk conversion. Also contained in the main dict are the following key/values, which are deprecated, should not be used, and will be removed in a future release: required or not. need to commit their pending RAID changes via a config job. final_ctls_to_phys_disk_ids = self._check_disks_status( mode, physical_disks, controllers_to_physical_disk_ids) controllers_to_results = {} in final_ctls_to_phys_disk_ids.items(): controllers_to_results[controller] = \ utils.build_return_dict( doc=None, resource_uri=None, is_commit_required_value=False, is_reboot_required_value=constants. RebootRequired.false) controllers_to_results[controller] = conversion_results # Remove the code below when is_reboot_required and # commit_required_ids are deprecated reboot_true = constants.RebootRequired.true reboot_optional = constants.RebootRequired.optional _is_reboot_required = \ conversion_results["is_reboot_required"] is_reboot_required = is_reboot_required \ or (_is_reboot_required in [reboot_true, reboot_optional]) controllers.append(controller) else: controllers_to_results[controller] = \ utils.build_return_dict( doc=None, resource_uri=None, is_commit_required_value=False, is_reboot_required_value=constants. RebootRequired.false) return {'conversion_results': controllers_to_results, 'is_reboot_required': is_reboot_required,
deleted_lines: :param controllers_to_physical_disk_ids: Dictionary of controllers we are inspecting and creating jobs for when needed. If needed modify this dict so that only drives that need to be changed to RAID or JBOD are in the list of disk keys for corresponding controller. """Convert disks RAID status and return a list of controller IDs Builds a list of controller ids that have had disks converted to the specified RAID status by: - Examining all the disks in the system and filtering out any that are not attached to a RAID/BOSS controller. - Inspect the controllers' disks to see if there are any that need to be converted, if so convert them. If a disk is already in the desired status the disk is ignored. Also check for failed or unknown disk statuses and raise an exception where appropriate. - Return a list of controller IDs for controllers whom have had any of their disks converted, and whether a reboot is required. The caller typically should then create a config job for the list of controllers returned to finalize the RAID configuration. :param mode: constants.RaidStatus enumeration used to determine what raid status to check for. corresponding disk ids we are inspecting and creating jobs for when needed. :returns: a dict containing the following key/values: required or not. need to commit their pending RAID changes via a config job. self._check_disks_status(mode, physical_disks, controllers_to_physical_disk_ids) in controllers_to_physical_disk_ids.items(): pass if conversion_results: reboot_true = constants.RebootRequired.true reboot_optional = constants.RebootRequired.optional _is_reboot_required = \ conversion_results["is_reboot_required"] is_reboot_required = is_reboot_required \ or (_is_reboot_required in [reboot_true, reboot_optional]) if conversion_results["is_commit_required"]: controllers.append(controller) return {'is_reboot_required': is_reboot_required,

commit_message:
bug-fix: set do_cleanup always True for libvirt driver

For libvirt, do_cleanup is just a flag to mark if the instance_path is shared.
If the instance path is shared, that means we shouldn't cleanup the target or
source instance path. But that code path is already controlled by 'destroy_disks'
flag.

We have two operations based on this do_cleanup flag:
   a) rpc call 'rollback_live_migration_at_destination' on source host when
      rollback live migration
   b) driver.cleanup on source host when post live migration
Both a) and b) have other logic like undefine the domain, disconnect volume or
destory vif except for cleanup instance path. These operations shouldn't be
controlled by only do_cleanup flag.

So set do_cleanup always True for libvirt driver to complete other cleanup
except for deleting instance path.

Change-Id: I83e82a8e7d92c09c64848d17b327acce34f52efa

commit_message:
Fix population of username, public keys

The expand function was failing to add the username and public keys to
the instances list. This change treats these arguments like other
defaults, and adds tests to confirm they're ending up in the instances
list.

This change also has a minor fix to the unprovision prompt validation
logic.

Change-Id: I603623511e4061e782a65d53a3118d211ea6e708

deleted_lines: if ssh_public_keys: inst['ssh_public_keys'] = ssh_public_keys if user_name: inst['user_name'] = user_name

commit_message:
ring: Flag region, zone, and device as required in add_dev

They effectively already *were*, but if you used the RingBuilder API
directly (rather than the CLI) you could previously write down builders
that would hit KeyErrors on load.

Change-Id: I1de895d4571f7464be920345881789d47659729f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/90/711790/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: required_keys = ('region', 'zone', 'ip', 'port', 'weight') missing = tuple(key for key in required_keys if key not in dev) if missing: raise ValueError('%r is missing required key(s): %s' % ( dev, ', '.join(missing)))
deleted_lines: required_keys = ('ip', 'port', 'weight') if any(required not in dev for required in required_keys): raise ValueError( '%r is missing at least one the required key %r' % ( dev, required_keys))

subject: Mark security group fullstack tests as stable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-02 14:24:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f9af5356006831e0ac4db4a3fc575a437e1667a4', 'message': "Mark security group fullstack tests as stable

It has been some time since we marked the security group tests in
fullstack as unstable.  Now that mark is impeding the fullstack tests

commit_message:
Mark security group fullstack tests as stable

It has been some time since we marked the security group tests in
fullstack as unstable.  Now that mark is impeding the fullstack tests
for stateless security groups.

Based on testing it appears that the unstable tests are specific to the
linuxbridge driver, which is not really very much supported these days.
Testing for that driver is dropped, since it is better to at least test
for the other scenarios than nothing at all.

Change-Id: Ib1ef0763496aa536ba80f1c34c64d8a6c313fd0b
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/710252
Related-bug: #1779328
